doc.after: Shostakovich was in many ways an obsessive man: according to his daughter he was "obsessed with cleanliness";[93] he synchronised the clocks in his apartment; he regularly sent cards to himself to test how well the postal service was working. Elizabeth Wilson's Shostakovich: A Life Remembered (1994 edition) indexes 26 references to his nervousness. Mikhail Druskin remembers that even as a young man the composer was "fragile and nervously agile".[94] Yuri Lyubimov comments, "The fact that he was more vulnerable and receptive than other people was no doubt an important feature of his genius".[95] In later life, Krzysztof Meyer recalled, "his face was a bag of tics and grimaces".[96]
